I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan of 
up to CNY230,000,000 to China Cube Water Limited (CCW) for the Asia Cube Wastewater 
Treatment Upgrade Project in the People’s Republic of China (PRC). 
 
2.  The proposed project will support private sector participation in expanding wastewater 
treatment (WWT) capacity and upgrading treatment and discharge standards at operating WWT 
plants alongside the capacity development of the East Asia Department (EARD) of the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) in the Yellow and Huai River basins in the PRC.1 
 
II.  THE PROJECT 
 
A.  Project Identification and Description 
 
3.  Project identification. The PRC is one of the most water-stressed countries in the world, 
with per capita water availability of about 2,000 cubic meters (m3), only one-quarter of the global 
average.2 Water scarcity in the PRC is further exacerbated by water pollution. Insufficient access 
to clean water has been described as one of the PRC’s most pressing bottlenecks to economic 
growth to 2030, and ADB has estimated an annual investment need of $60 billion per year for 
water supply and sanitation in the PRC.3 
 
4.  Because of uneven distribution of water resources, water scarcity is particularly severe in 
the Yellow and Huai River basins (footnote 1). Water security remains a key constraint for the 
basins as they are prone to natural hazards and adverse impacts from climate change, such as 
severe droughts and flooding. For instance, more than three-quarters of the Yellow River basin 
area is defined as ecologically fragile, with its total water resources shrinking by 13.4% since 1990 
(footnote 2). 
 
5.  In recognition of the critical nature of water security, provincial governments along the river 
basins are increasingly introducing stricter local WWT discharge standards that are higher than 
the national requirements.4 ADB, through EARD, is supporting the government  in capacity 
development and in designing the Yellow River ecological corridor framework which focuses on 
protecting the fragile ecological environment of the Yellow River basin, balancing the use and 
preservation of water resources, and promoting high-quality green development. Through a One 
ADB approach, ADB’s Private Sector Operations Department identified a private sector solution 
to complement EARD’s initiatives for water sustainability in key river basins in the PRC. 
 
6.  Project design. The project will support the expansion of WWT capacity and upgrade of 
treatment and discharge standards at operating WWT plants mainly in third- and fourth-tier cities, 
with a focus on the Yellow and Huai River basins.5 The project is designed to support private 
sector participation in protecting the water environment in the PRC. Further, the project will bundle

projects typically too small and expensive for international banks to finance on a stand-alone 
basis. As such, the project is designed to be a least-cost solution to financing smaller-scale WWT 
upgrade and expansion projects in the PRC. 
 
7.  Under the project, ADB will disburse funds to selected subprojects subject to defined 
environmental, social, development, and financial criteria. Eligible capital expenditure items will 
include constructing, upgrading, expanding, and refinancing the subprojects. [CONFIDENTIAL 
INFORMATION DELETED] 
 
8.  Each subproject involves a public–private partnership arrangement with a municipal 
government based on template contracts set forth in national concession guidelines. In each case, 
the  specific  expansion  and/or  upgrade  infrastructure  will  depend  on  development  and 
environmental needs as determined by municipal governments. The facilities will be required to 
comply with ADB’s safeguards, gender mainstreaming, and other policy requirements. 
 
9.  The sponsor. Asia Cube Water Limited (ACW), the sponsor, is a 100% privately owned 
WWT company with nine operating projects serving more than 2 million residential and industrial 
consumers in Guangdong, Heilongjiang, Henan, and Shaanxi provinces in the PRC. All ACW 
operations are consolidated under its wholly owned onshore subsidiary, China Cube Water 
Limited (CCW), the borrower. ACW holds its ownership in CCW through a holding company 
registered in Hong Kong, China—China Water Cube Limited (CWC), the guarantor. 
 
10.  The borrower. CCW began operating as a WWT utility in 2011 and had a total operating 
capacity of 207,500 m3 per day as of December 2020. Seventy percent of CCW’s capacity is in 
Henan and Shaanxi provinces, along the Huai and Yellow River basins. Further, CCW has 
additional capacity of 105,000 m3 per day under development and construction, located near or 
adjacent to its Huai and Yellow River basin projects. CCW distinguishes itself from other WWT 
operators in the PRC by its technological expertise and operational excellence. [CONFIDENTIAL 
INFORMATION DELETED] 
 
11.  Shareholders. ACW is wholly owned by I Squared Capital Advisors LLC (ISQ), an 
international infrastructure private equity firm. In Asia, ISQ has deployed more than $2.6 billion in 
investments, owning, and managing projects in renewable energy, environmental protection, 
telecommunications, data centers, and highways. Since its acquisition in 2014, ISQ has brought 
in a highly qualified and experienced management team to CCW and introduced initiatives to 
increase efficiency, such as implementing a rigorous investment approval process, streamlining 
operational processes, and optimizing variable costs such as electricity and chemical costs. 
 
12.  [CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED] 
 
13.  Pandemic  impacts.  CCW  has  a  large  operational  footprint  in  Henan  and  Shaanxi 
provinces—neighboring provinces to Hubei, the epicenter of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) 
outbreak. CCW acted on municipal government requests to ensure uninterrupted WWT to 
residential and industrial consumers so that essential activities were supported as the economy 
attempted to recover from the COVID-19 pandemic. Though CCW experienced a delay in tariff 
repayment from local governments in the first 6 months of the outbreak, the overall impact has 
been limited as the tariff payments have now resumed per the regular payments cycle. Therefore, 
COVID-19 has not had a material long-term impact on CCW’s project costs or capacity. ADB’s 
support  for  private  sector  participation  in  building  and  maintaining  critical  infrastructure  is 
expected to help local governments ensure resilience in their pandemic recovery efforts. Further,

3 
the subprojects will provide local jobs and a more inclusive work environment for male and female 
employees. 
 
B.  Development Impacts, Outcome, and Outputs 
 
14.  Impacts.  The  project  is  aligned  with  the  following  impacts:  access  to  wastewater 
management for residential and industrial users enhanced, and the urban environment improved 
in the PRC.6 
 
15.  Outcome. The project will have the following outcome: provision of WWT services mainly 
in third- and fourth-tier cities, with a focus on the Yellow and Huai River basins increased and/or 
improved to meet higher local discharge standards.7 
 
16.  Outputs. The project will have the following outputs: (i) capacity of WWT plants expanded 
and/or effluent discharge upgraded, (ii) budget of local city governments in the PRC supported, 
(iii) local employment generated, and (iv) gender equality in the workplace strengthened. 
 
C.  Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations 
 
17.  Consistency with ADB strategy. The project is aligned with Strategy 2030’s operational 
priority 4 (making cities more livable) by reducing pollution through expansion of WWT capacity 
and by supporting water quality improvements through higher discharge standards of treated 
wastewater. The project is also consistent with Strategy 2030’s operational priority 2 (accelerating 
progress in gender equality) with measures designed to promote gender-sensitive solutions and 
gender-responsive  infrastructure  assets.  Further, the  project  contributes  to  Strategy  2030’s 
operational priority 1 (addressing remaining poverty and reducing inequalities) by providing 
employment during the project’s construction and operation phases, and operational priority 3 
(tackling climate change, building climate and disaster resilience, and enhancing environmental 
sustainability) by providing additional capacity to treat wastewater. The project supports the 
strategic priorities of ADB’s country partnership strategy for the PRC, 2021–2025 to address 
environmental degradation through mainstreaming private sector solutions for environmental 
infrastructure.8 
 
18.  Lessons  from  previous  operations.  The  project  will  benefit  from  ADB’s  broad 
experience in mobilizing investment from the private sector to support sustainable development 
in the water infrastructure value chain in the PRC. Key lessons from previous operations include 
(i) water utilities with private investment typically outperform those owned by municipalities;9 
(ii) effective  policy  dialogue  on  cost  recovery  benefits  urban  water  planning  and  ensures 
investment sustainability; 10 (iii) there is a need to adopt an integrated approach, treating water 
systems together with the catchment area as a complete ecosystem;11 (iv) there is a need for 
innovative technology (smart systems based on information and communication technology) to

G.  Unique Features 
 
22.  The project is ADB’s first to support upgrades in the treatment of municipal and industrial 
wastewater to increase the quality of treated wastewater beyond the highest national wastewater 
standards. The project was originated and structured through a strong One ADB approach 
undertaken  by  ADB’s  EARD  and  Private  Sector  Operations  Department  in  the  PRC  and 
complements the Yellow River ecological corridor framework currently being designed by EARD. 
The project includes tracking pollutants  such as heavy metals, oil hydrocarbons,  inorganic 
nitrogen, phosphate, and organic matter that are listed as pollutants to be controlled under ADB’s 
Action Plan for Healthy Oceans.14 Finally, supporting a private sector sponsor with expertise in 
deploying technology and operational efficiency in urban water projects will provide an opportunity 
to extract lessons learned to further encourage private sector participation in addressing one of 
the PRC’s most critical development needs. 
 
III.  THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  The Assistance 
 
23.  ADB’s assistance to CCW is a senior loan of up to CNY230 million from its ordinary capital 
resources. [CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION DELETED] 
 
 
B.  Value Added by ADB Assistance 
 
24.  ADB’s assistance provides the following additionality: 
(i)  Financial additionality. Compared to its peers which are mostly state-owned 
entities, CCW has extremely limited access to long-term financing from local 
commercial banks. In particular, financing for upgrading existing WWT plants to 
meet higher water quality standards is difficult to obtain because of the lack of 
additional collateral. Without ADB’s support, CCW would need to fund the required 
capital expenditure either entirely through equity or pledge other debt-free projects 
as collateral. By aggregating a series of upgrade and expansion subprojects which 
are too small to be financed on a stand-alone basis with an operating portfolio, 
ADB will structure a single optimum financing solution for CCW, reduce transaction 
costs, and bring a cofinancier to the project. 
(ii)  Nonfinancial additionality. ADB will work with CCW to establish a corporate 
environmental and social management system (ESMS) as a condition precedent 
to the first disbursement. ADB’s engagement will promote gender inclusiveness in 
CCW’s operations and support the implementation of CCW’s gender-sensitive 
practices in its human resources policies and in the workplace. Through a One 
ADB approach, the key lessons from this project on WWT through a river basin 
approach will be shared with other developing member countries.

IV.  POLICY COMPLIANCE 
 
A.  Safeguards and Social Dimensions 
 
26.  ADB  has  categorized  the  investment  in  compliance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy 
Statement (2009) as follows: environment category B, involuntary resettlement category B, and 
indigenous peoples category C.15 
 
27.  ADB has undertaken due diligence and reviewed the potential environmental and social 
(E&S) impacts of the project and the measures to avoid, minimize, mitigate, and compensate for 
adverse impacts in the safeguard reports and plans. Corrective actions were identified to ensure 
that CCW’s E&S measures and institutional capacity and commitment to manage the project’s 
E&S impacts will be adequate. 
 
28.  External consultants conducted an audit of CCW’s existing corporate ESMS and E&S 
compliance audits of nine subprojects that will be supported by the ADB loan. At the time of the 
E&S audit, nine subprojects were in operation and only one subproject had ongoing construction 
activities. The audits did not find any potential significant adverse, irreversible, diverse, or 
unprecedented E&S impacts that may be caused by the upgrade, expansion, and operation of 
CCW subprojects. Auxiliary facilities such as pipelines and sludge treatment stations are built, 
operated, and maintained by local governments and will not be financed by the ADB loan. The 
subprojects are not located in or adjacent to any legally protected areas; critical habitats; or areas 
of cultural, historical, or religious significance. In each case, the local government determines the 
location of the subprojects based on the local land use planning. Treated wastewater from each 
subproject is discharged to water bodies designated by the government and is strictly monitored 
against the applicable effluent discharge standards by the local Ecology and Environmental 
Bureau through a real-time wastewater online monitoring system. Based on the screening using 
the AWARE for Projects tool, the climate risk rating for each subproject ranges from medium to 
high because of floods, storms, and snow loading. Since site selections were based on local land 
use planning and national and local standards for flood control, the potential climate risk may be 
low  to  medium.  The  corrective  action  includes  developing  and  adopting  a  supplementary 
emergency response plan in case of floods. 
 
29.  CCW has environment, health, and safety (EHS) policies and procedures for its subproject 
operation and maintenance, including equipment maintenance, influent and effluent quality, 
chemical use, occupational health and safety, accident and incident management, and COVID-
19 prevention and control. The EHS procedures are cascaded to the subprojects and are adjusted 
to comply with requirements in the concession agreements and/or with the applicable regulations. 
 
30.  The audits recommended corrective actions to ensure that  relevant procedures are 
adequate  and  compliant  with  applicable  national  and  local  laws  and  regulations,  good 
international industry practices, and ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009) requirements. 
Specifically,  CCW  will  (i)  apply  ADB’s  prohibited  investment  activities  list,  (ii)  ensure  that 
subprojects that use ADB funds comply with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement and abide by 
national  laws  and  regulations,  (iii)  establish  and  maintain  an  appropriate  corporate  ESMS 
 
15 ADB. Safeguard Categories.

7 
satisfactory to ADB before disbursement, (iv) develop and implement formal subproject ESMSs, 
(v) establish coordinated corporate and subproject EHS management mechanisms, (vi) develop 
and  implement  an  EHS  training  program,  and  (vii)  implement  corrective  actions  for  each 
subproject-specific issue identified during the audits. A time-bound corrective action plan will be 
discussed and agreed with CCW. 
 
31.  CCW’s human resource management policies and procedures applicable to direct full-
time and short-term employees at corporate and subproject levels were assessed in the audits 
as being compliant with national laws and regulations and include measures to comply with 
internationally recognized core labor standards, pursuant to ADB’s Social Protection Strategy 
(2001). Policy enhancement opportunities have been identified regarding specific coverage of 
subcontractor labor contracting and maximizing local recruitment, which are included in the 
corrective action plan. The ESMS will set out requirements, as applicable, for compliance with 
national labor laws and measures to comply with the internationally recognized core labor 
standards,  pursuant  to  ADB’s  Social  Protection  Strategy.  The  ESMS  will  also  contain 
requirements, as applicable, for grievance redress management and information disclosure and 
consultation with affected people following ADB requirements. CCW will report regularly to ADB 
on (i) its E&S performance and that of its subprojects, including compliance with applicable laws; 
and (ii) the measures taken.16 
 
32.  Some gender elements. The project is classified as having some gender elements. The 
gender analysis conducted during due diligence concluded that CCW operates in accordance 
with national regulations governing gender equality in the workplace. The nature of work at WWT 
plants makes it difficult to have balanced participation in technical and operational jobs in line with 
the national average, yet CCW maintains consistent female representation in its management 
teams. Since January 2021, the PRC has had its first national legislation in place obliging 
companies to adopt measures to prevent and respond to sexual harassment in the workplace.17 
CCW is committed to having responsive business practices and, notably, initiated an anti-sexual-
harassment policy. Following ADB’s Policy on Gender and Development, CCW has incorporated 
measures to promote gender equality and women’s empowerment in its business activities, 
fostering  a  gender-inclusive  environment. 18  These  measures  relate  to  the  effective 
implementation of its new anti-sexual-harassment policy through active communication with 
employees at headquarters and at the plants, using digital and other channels to disseminate key 
messages on this topic, and its integration into the human resource onboarding program. CCW 
will also further enhance its facilities to be more gender responsive by setting up designated 
nursing rooms at all plants. CCW will submit periodic reports on its implementation of the 
proposed gender measures to ADB. 
 
B.  Anticorruption Policy 
 
33.  CCW was advised of ADB’s policy of implementing best international practice relating to 
combating corruption, money laundering, and the financing of terrorism. ADB will ensure that the 
investment  documentation  includes  appropriate  provisions  prohibiting  corruption,  money 
laundering, and the financing of terrorism; and remedies for ADB in the event of noncompliance.

D.  Assurances 
 
35.  Consistent with the Agreement Establishing the Asian Development Bank (the Charter),19 
ADB will proceed with the proposed assistance upon establishing that the Government of the 
PRC has no objection to the proposed assistance to CCW. ADB will enter into suitable finance 
documentation, in form and substance satisfactory to ADB, following approval of the proposed 
assistance by the ADB Board of Directors. 
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
36.  I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the loan of up to 
CNY230,000,000 from ADB’s ordinary capital resources to China Cube Water Limited for the Asia 
Cube Wastewater Treatment Upgrade Project in the People’s Republic of China, with such terms 
and conditions as are substantially in accordance with those set forth in this report, and as may 
be reported to the Board. 
 
Masatsugu Asakawa

The proposed project will support private sector participation in expanding wastewater treatment (WWT) capacity and upgrading treatment and discharge standards at operating WWT plants alongside the capacity development of the East Asia Department (EARD) of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) in the Yellow and Huai River basins in the People's Republic of China.

The report and recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors (RRP) document describes the terms and conditions of a project for consideration and approval by ADB's Board of Directors.

This document dated April 2021 is provided for the ADB project 54401-001 in the People's Republic of China.
